{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/doctors-to-get-panic-button/article_352d8fc2-f629-50fd-a98a-3ed70e78d260.html", "TITLE": " Doctors to get PANIC button ", "DATE": "May 24, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "A PANIC button is expected to be installed soon at the Emergency Department of the San Fernando General Hospital. This is just one of the measures the hospital will be undertaking to protect its staff from irate patients and relatives. Last Friday, hospital officials met with the Medical Professionals Association of Trinidad and Tobago (MPATT) to discuss safety measures after a member of staff was attacked at the Port of Spain General Hospital and a doctor at the San Fernando Teaching Hospital was slapped. Chief executive officer of the South West Regional Health Authority (SWRHA) Anil Gosine said panic buttons will be installed in various parts of the hospital deemed \"hotspots\", starting with the Emergency Department. He said: \"We will start with the hotspots in some of the areas. We have already implemented panic buttons in the psychiatry department. These panic buttons when pressed will sound an alarm so that security can attend to the situation.\" Gosine said he did not want to reveal all the departments termed \"hotpsots.\" He added: \"We looked at putting up signs now to protect our staff. We do have signs to protect the staff but we need to modify it. We need to have a system in place so that in the long term if some-one continues to come to the San Fernando General Hospital and continually pose a threat to the staff, we will find ways of having that person evicted.\" The signs would be at every ward stating that abuse by patients or relatives would not be tolerated. Gosine said a meeting was also held with the San Fernando Doctors' Association and some measures raised by the association were discussed. Some were already implemented he said. Some of those measures already implemented were having security escort staff to their vehicles at night, there was a hotline number for staff to call in case of an emergency and he said security personnel were increased in areas \"that we expect may have disputes with patients and patients' relatives.\" Gosine said discussions will be ongoing with the San Fernando Doctors' Association. ? {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/arima-hospital-to-get-m-health-facility/article_ef3b2774-698b-5aa3-a003-81176f226b55.html", "TITLE": " Arima hospital to get $30m health facility ", "DATE": "Mar 14, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "Arima is expected to benefit from the state-of-the-art Arima Diagnostic Clinic (ADC) and Research Institute at 25-28 Hollis Avenue, close to Arima Velodrome. The $30 million facility will boast two operating theatres, inpatient facilities, a 24-hour accident and emergency specialist clinic, a healthy eating restaurant and obstetric services. Rev Dr Margaret Elcock, president/CEO of the Family Focus Broadcasting Network and ISAAC 98.1, paid kudos to hospital CEO Helen Alleyne and her family at the launch and dinner celebration at the banquet hall of Eastern Credit Union, Sorzano Street, Arima, on Saturday night. Alleyne was also hailed as a pioneer, since she started the first school of ultrasound sciences and several speakers who brought greetings called for Alleyne to be conferred with a national award during Independence celebrations on August 31. Elcock labelled Alleyne a visionary, in the presence of her spouse/managing director Benjamin Alleyne and children Doctor of Engineering (PhD) Ian, medical doctor Ron, hospital manager Megan and University of Trinidad and Tobago (UTT) biomedical engineering student Okon. The matriarch of the family, Alleynes 90-year-old mother Olive Caton, whom she described as the best business adviser, also attended the vent. They were joined by Hamid OBrien, adviser to Minister of Health Dr Fuad Khan, Justice Lloyd Elcock, Accreditation Council of Trinidad and Tobago (ACTT) executive director Michael Bradshaw, chairperson Nicole Larsen, Newsday editor-in-chief Jones P Madeira, medical doctors Spencer Perkins and Daniel Otajele and Bishop Andrew John, who said the commissioning prayer. Another highlight of the elegant evening was the presentation of awards to deserving employees. The ADC is a vision whose time has come. I am deeply moved because I am witnessing the fulfilment of the vision of Helen, one of my dearest friends. When she shared her dream, we would laugh a lot about these crazy ideas. God opened incredible doors that only he could. Her dreams came to pass, said Elcock. As a visionary, you learn certain principles, people will always be there waiting to help you. If you have no dream or if you do not begin to act on it, the people who are supposed to help you wont know where to find you, she added. Slipping into her motivational speaker role, Elcock imparted kernels of wisdom to the audience. Write your vision down. Make it plain and articulate it. Be careful whom you allow to influence you. Your vision can either be encouraged or destroyed by others. People have the potential to create your environment. Your environment determines your mindset, your mindset determines your future. Choose your friends wisely. OBrien said it was important to form public and private partnerships to assist the population. He also spoke about the dialysis programme which Minister Khan had unveiled to improve time and reduce costs. He also said health tourism can only be successful if Trinidad and Tobago can provide quality health care institutions. He said the Ministry had signed a memorandum of understanding with COSTAAT/Skills Training to develop a nursing programme and arrest the critical demand for nurses. OBrien lauded Alleyne for having the vision to establish a diagnostic centre. During her remarks, Alleyne, a radiographer, said the clinic was born out of a passion for providing health care services, including ultrasound, X-rays and mammograms. I was acutely aware of the absence of the imaging sciences, there was no medical science. Little did I know at that time the provision of these basic services would lead to opportunities for providing full medical services, she said. Alleyne said her family has learnt to rely upon Gods unchanging love and the grace so freely given through faith in Jesus Christ. Baptiste-Cornelis spoke with reporters on Monday after the launch of the Electronic Birth Registration System at the San Fernando General Hospital. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/doctors-in-pain/article_92925908-07c4-5cbf-86bf-a2a6be980803.html", "TITLE": " DOCTORS IN PAIN ", "DATE": "Dec 24, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " House officers at the Port of Spain General Hospital say the chronic shortage of staff and non-payment of overtime at the hospital are becoming untenable. The doctors claim that since May they have not been paid overtime. If the situation does not improve, health care at the hospital could be heading towards crisis proportions soon, doctors told the Express. According to their contracts, the doctors must work seven sessions per month, and must be compensated for working additional sessions. To deal with the staff shortage however, house officers are working as many as ten sessions and are yet to be compensated. The Express spoke with one such doctor yesterday who has accrued more than $20,000 in overtime. He described the distress he and his colleagues are currently experiencing as a result of not being paid overtime since May. He said the doctors were afraid to speak out publicly, fearing that they would lose their jobs. \"The situation is so distressing, we keep working the extra sessions, hoping that things will change but months have gone by and still we have not been paid for overtime. These doctors have to pay rent, mortgage, car loans, and since many of the doctors are foreigners, they also need to see about their families back home. It is not fair, what kind of message is being sent to foreigners coming here to work\" he asked. \"It's not motivation that is driving us because right now the doctors aren't motivated. Our consciences are what's driving us to continue because we know that we can't compromise health care, we can't leave our patients to suffer because that will not be fair to them.\" The doctor claimed that the hospital medical chief of staff, Dr Colin Furlonge, has advised the doctors to adjust their rosters so that each doctor works their stipulated seven sessions. \"We have tried this recommendation, but because there are not enough doctors to be spread around, it is not possible for doctors to work just seven sessions. If every doctor decides that he or she will work only seven sessions, then you will have other sessions that are unaccounted for,\" he said. Furlonge could not be reached for comment yesterday. In early December, Health Minister Dr Fuad Khan announced that a new batch of Cuban doctors and nurses had arrived in Trinidad. While an influx of nurses and specialists is a welcome sight, the house officers at the hospital contend that junior doctors are specially needed to work on the wards and ground levels of the hospital. This is not the first time problems affecting junior doctors at the hospital have been brought to attention. Several weeks ago an unsigned letter listing a number of grievances among junior doctors was circulated to media houses. Among the claims made in the letter were that junior doctors have to spend money hiring attorneys to get monies owed to them by the North West Regional Health Authority and that accident and emergency junior doctors are being denied compensatory days for public holidays. The letter also stated that junior doctors must work under poor conditions and use poor unsafe on-call facilities. \"There is a false belief that being a doctor is a noble profession, we urge parents to guide their children otherwise. Being a doctor in T&T is real hell and this situation is a national shame,\" the letter concluded. In response to a few questions sent to the board of the NWRHA regarding the contents of the letter, the Express was told that a meeting was held between management and doctors to discuss the matter of compensation and that another meeting was scheduled to take place. But a doctor speaking on the condition of anonymity said the second meeting was cancelled and the doctors still do not know when they will be compensated for working extra sessions. When contacted yesterday, Health Minister Dr Fuad Khan said he had not been apprised of the issue regarding overtime payments. He added that it must be investigated. The minister also said the doctors affected should write him directly on the matter. \"We are not fighting with government or with management but doctors are humans too. And so we expect management to make the work environment more conducive for their staff to thrive and provide more doctors and not compromise the health care of its citizens,\" said an aggrieved doctor. On March 1, Dr Javed Chinnia performed a Caesarean section on Cottle at the Mt Hope Womens Hospital during which baby Simeons head was sliced open. On instructions of Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar, Attorney General Anand Ramlogan appointed a committee to investigate the death. This team comprised chairman and retired Appeal Court judge Mustapha Ibrahim, neonatologist Dr Petronella Manning-Alleyne and consultant obstetrician/gynaecologist Dr Melanie Clare Davis of the UK. The committees report has stated that baby Simeons injury occurred from failure to exercise the degree of skill which was required in order to perform the surgery. It also stated that a prima facie case of medical negligence may have been made out following Chinnias admission that a surgical error was to be blamed for the babys death. The committee advised that the medical disciplinary authorities as constituted under the Medical Board Act Chapter 29:50 should determine the necessary course of action in this case. Speaking to the Express by phone yesterday, Cottle said she was surprised to see the report findings in the newspapers. She said she feels like a fool because she met with Health Minister Dr Fuad Khan at the Parliament last Friday and when she asked for a copy of the report she was told she cannot get it until released to the Parliament. She said Khan told her she can view the report tomorrow. I feel like its some pappyshow because my baby died and I cant get a copy of the report on how he died but it was given to the media, said Cottle. Nevertheless, Cottle said based on the media reports it is clear that the doctor who did the surgery was to blame as both she and her husband had said from day one. I think he should be punished, they should take away his licence so he cannot make any more mistakes, said Cottle. She said she asked Khan what action will be taken against the doctor and he told her it was a case for the Medical Board to determine. This thing real affecting me. I feel as though I did wrong and the doctor is the victim. My baby died because of him, said Cottle. I will leave it in the hands of God but I really do not want to be one to say that I did not get justice, Cottle added. She reiterated her call for a copy of the report and expressed hope that proper action would be taken against the doctor . Chinnia was suspended with basic pay following baby Simeons death. T&T won 3-1 and play their final group match today against Guyana from 7 p.m. at Hasely Crawford Stadium. \u0097Photo: JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK EVASIVE ACTION: Trinidad and Tobago winger Akeem Garcia, left, skips past Suriname goalkeeper Savio Proeger during Caribbean Football Union (CFU) Under-17 World Cup qualifying action on Thursday night at Ato Boldon Stadium in Balmain, Couva. T&T won 3-1 and play their final group match today against Guyana from 7 p.m. at Hasely Crawford Stadium. \u0097Photo: JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK When I was a youngster and there was the occasional photograph in the press of a newly qualified doctor, all bedecked in his graduation gown, I used to think that here is a young modern doctor who therefore knows more than the old fogies here. Little did I know that at graduation one only begins to learn the practice of medicine and before that it is mostly book learning. I have already told the story of my first day after graduation when in my Dublin teaching hospital a patient to whom I was speaking suddenly suffered a heart attack and how I panicked, forgetting what dose of this and that should be given in such an emergency. The head nurse had to come to my rescue! In fact, several years ago we deemed that there should be a two-year instead of a one-year internship period before being granted full registration. However, it appears that as far as the university is concerned, their responsibility ends on graduation day, and they seem to be relatively unconcerned about the level of supervision which their interns receive in the hospitals. It is as though once the baby is delivered, there is no interest in the postpartum care. How well I remember the utter distress of a newly-qualified young intern who came complaining to me that she was left unsupervised in a pediatric ward. As she cried, trembling slightly: \"But children die so easily.\" Now, when in 1967 it was decided to decentralise the teaching of medicine from the Mona Campus in Jamaica to include teaching in the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Barbados and the Port of Spain General Hospital, one reason which was put forward to justify the initiative was that the interns should be taught in the hospitals where they will eventually work, and that the new university-appointed staff should try to raise the standard of medicine and academia in these government-run hospitals. I do believe that we did succeed to a certain extent with that in the early days but it was blood sweat and tears and even in those days there were major staffing problems. A typical medical (or surgical) firm should comprise a consultant, a registrar, a house-officer and an intern or two as a minimum. Registrars in the United Kingdom, for example, are those who are pursuing postgraduate training in order to achieve specialist status. Usually in internal medicine, they already have the diploma of the Membership of the Royal College of Physicians (MRCP) and in surgical firms, the FRCS (Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons), which are not per se recognised degrees for specialist status. They generally stay in that post for about four years and then move on to wherever to make room for other registrars. This is very important. As an aside, this reminds me of a well-known practice in the days when I sat the examination. That degree from Edinborough, for example, is designated MRCP(E) and from Ireland it is MRCP(I). Many students from India used to come to the UK to sit this prestigious examination. Most failed but they would then return to India and put MRCP(F) on the large shingles outside their private offices to impress the patient. Of course, and deceptively so, (F) could stand for (France) or (Finland) or wherever. However, their (F) really stood for \"Failed.\" Legally therefore, the doctor did not lie! In the UK, registrars are not allowed private practice. They are in the hospital all day and are a most important anchor, liaising with the consultant and are also involved in the teaching and supervision of the junior house-officers and interns. In fact, in certain practical ways I learned more from my registrar than from the consultants. I will only refer to the Port of Spain General Hospital because I know relatively little about the others but I am sure that they suffer the same problem. A suitably qualified registrar is a rarity in the hospital's medical firms. Unfortunately, those who do have the MRCP diploma frequently consider themselves specialists when they are not and, to make matters worse, they quickly set up a private practice and you cannot find most of them after 1 p.m. in the hospitals. Attention Ministry of Health! But hospitals are where the most interesting, challenging and difficult medicine is seen and, as is found in the great First World hospitals, there must be strict discipline, proper staffing, good management and, last but not least, inspirational and exemplary registrars, consultants and heads of departments. In fact, any hospital without such a cadre of staff cannot be worthy of being chosen to be a teaching hospital since, among many other things, without such seniors the supervision and training of young doctors will be severely compromised as will any attempt to provide an academic atmosphere which is so essential for excellence. This discourages some young doctors. And so, they leave for this and other reasons. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/doctor-i-was-never-hired/article_b927432f-87f8-5aaf-8b6b-c1b59fe21678.html", "TITLE": " Doctor: I was never hired ", "DATE": "Jul 29, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Dr Richard Spann, the neurosurgeon blamed for leaving patients in the lurch at public hospitals, has said he was never a member of staff at these institutions. He said he had been volunteering his services for years at the San Fernando General Hospital and the Mount Hope Medical Sciences Complex with the understanding that the Ministry of Health would find a replacement. The UK trained Dr Spann continues to work full time at the Community Hospital of Seventh Day Adventists in Port of Spain, where he also is the chief executive officer, and still volunteers his services at the public hospitals. On Wednesday, a woman who took her eight-month-old baby for help at the San Fernando General Hospital, was told she had to go to Port of Spain. She was one of several people turned away from the south hospital because of the absence of a specialist to treat head and brain injuries. Contacted yesterday for comment on his \"sudden resignation\" that left almost 50 patients, including eight children, in need of specialist neurological attention, Spann said he had informed Health Minister Therese Baptiste-Cornelis by letter of his decision to sever his volunteer services about a week ago. Spann said he had many conversations with officials at both institutions about finding replacements. \"I have been working in Trinidad for ten years, but I have never worked as a member of staff in any public health institution. I was always employed at Community Hospital but from time to time I was asked to help out at the public institutions (San Fernando General Hospital) and Mount Hope. I agreed to do so until these institutions could get a neurosurgeon on staff,\" he said. Spann said he extended himself between three hospitals and nothing was seemingly being done at the Ministry of Health to find a solution. However, the extremely long hours and hectic duties began taking a toll on his personal and family life, he said. The doctor said it was impossible for him to give the effective care that some patients needed at these hospitals. He has been serving at the San Fernando hospital since 2008, but because it was impossible for him to visit patients daily, he suggested that the patients who needed urgent daily care and surgery be transferred to the Community Hospital at which he worked. In 2008 that was done, but no contracts were signed and monies are still owed for services provided, he said. He also responded to Baptiste-Cornelis' claim that $30 million was owed to private institutions by the South West Regional Health Authority, and concerns that patients being kept too long at the institutions. Spann however said, \"All that money is not owed to us. And some of these patients with brain and spinal injuries need round the clock attention, but we cannot ever say stop the service on a patient in need. That's an ethical issue there.\" He believes many doctors opt out of the public institutions because they are frustrated in trying to provide health care in the midst of staff shortages, inadequate equipment, lack of drugs and other ongoing problems. There are nine specialist neurosurgeons in the country with three at the Port of Spain General Hospital, three in private practice and three retired. If called upon by the Health Minister, Spann said these professionals could make recommendations to resolve the problem at the health institutions while, hopefully, younger doctors are encouraged to specialise. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/foreign-doctors-for-health-sector/article_def06ea1-b5c1-538e-b7eb-81a507b9f7d6.html", "TITLE": " 119 foreign doctors for health sector ", "DATE": "Aug 7, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "FIVE hundred and thirty-four foreign medical professionals, including 119 doctors, are scheduled to start arriving in this country from as early as next week in order to fill the gaps within the health sector, according to Parliamentary Secretary in the Ministry of Health, Senator Wesley George. \"They are coming in batches and I understand that the first batch would be coming in from Cuba and they would be distributed evenly throughout the regions in all sorts of specialties across the board,\" he said. George, who said the ministry hoped that within the next five years they would \"have no need for foreign health professionals because our own Trinidadians and Tobagonians would have been trained and registered in every available vacancy in our public health system\", was speaking to the Express after the graduation ceremony for Operating Theatre Nurses at the Eric Williams Medical Sciences Complex yesterday when he made the statements. At Boodoo-Ramsoomair's funeral last Saturday, Legal Affairs Minister Prakash Ramadhar said Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar had called for measures to be put in place to ensure there is no repeat of the incident. The decision to suspend the medical workers, which she admitted was a first for the ministry, was made by SWRHA's chief executive officer Paula Chester Cumberbatch. \"It should be noted that the suspension was not seen directly as a penalty, but it more represents the fact that we must ensure public confidence is rekindled in our system and we have promised transparency and accountability to all our nationals,\" she said. Heading this committee is chairman of the SWRHA, Dr Lackram Boodoo. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/superior-health-care-at-sangre-grande-hospital/article_ad3f0e74-56d8-5e1a-8a22-00545a57817c.html", "TITLE": " 'Superior health care' at Sangre Grande Hospital ", "DATE": "Jan 13, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "focus on customer service: Eastern Regional Health Authority CEO Stacy Harricharan at the ERHA offices on Eastern Main Road, Sangre Grande. focus on customer service: Eastern Regional Health Authority CEO Stacy Harricharan at the ERHA offices on Eastern Main Road, Sangre Grande. THE MOTHER of nine-year-old Ariel Rostant was looking for a medical institution to perform eye surgery on her daughter. She was told at the Eric Williams Medical Sciences Complex, Mt Hope that she would have to wait a few years for the surgery, while the Sangre Grande Hospital informed her it could be done within a few weeks. She made the obvious choice. Following the successful retinal implant surgery last Wednesday Rostant's mother has heaped praise on the hospital staff. \"(The service) was excellent, the doctors are very caring, and considerate, I recommend they get more funding,\" she told the Sunday Express yesterday in a telephone interview. She said that the doctors were \"extremely polite\", nurses \"par excellence\" and she also found them \"very caring and considerate\". \"I have the highest esteem and regard for them,\" she added. This was one of a number of positive reports the Sunday Express has received from patients at the Sangre Grande Hospital which falls under the purview of the Eastern Regional Health Authority (ERHA). The ERHA, with the hospital, 15 health centres and the Mayaro District Health Facility, provides coverage for 130,000 people from Matelot down to Guayaguayare across to Rio Claro and up to Cumuto. ERHA chief executive Stacy Harricharan, speaking to the Sunday Express on Friday at the ERHA's offices in Sangre Grande, said it was about one-third of the land mass of the country but it was very disparate which has been one of the challenges for them. Asked if they got a lot of traffic from outside the catchment area, Harricharan said \"of course we do\", noting that the attraction was the \"superior health care\". ERHA quality manager Keith Beharry said they got patients from surrounding areas like Arima but also from other parts of the country. \"We get people from even as far as Diego Martin sometimes coming to Grande just for the service. (For) our maternity ward (women from) as far as South will come just to deliver at Grande. The name Sangre Grande Hospital speaks for itself,\" he added. He said a main attraction was good waiting times for both surgical and medical services including same day emergency ultrasound, routine cases and urgent cases for CT scans could be done almost immediately. \"Routine cases for diagnostic reviews can be done within three to four weeks, that as well is unheard of really in the sector but it's because of the management of the cases,\" he added. Harricharan recalled hearing positive reports about the hospital prior to becoming CEO in August last year. \"Like everybody else, I had heard the great things about Sangre Grande Hospital so I had a lot of preconceived notions of it being very good in terms of patient care and service delivery,\" she commented. Harricharan stressed that they take a \"customer service view\" of the service they offer at the hospital and all the ERHA's health centres and outreach centres. She said one of the first things that struck her at the hospital was the \"smiling faces\", possibly a product of the \"Miles of Smiles\" initiative launched in 2009 \"to engender in employees the willingness to cooperate with the patient\". Beharry said the initiative was for the staff to understand their role in the sector and how to help a patient or address one with a concern who may feel they are not getting adequate attention. \"The focus really was on ensuring that the Sangre Grande Hospital really became a customer service organisation and I think we have been able to accomplish that in the last couple years,\" he said. He noted that the training was multi-disciplinary with a wide range of staff including doctors, nurses, clerks and attendants. He said after the training there was monitoring on a monthly basis via patient discharge surveys which cover from point of entry to exit, ascertaining what patients liked and areas of improvement. The survey includes attitude of all staff, cleanliness of ward areas, comfort, ability to rest, meals, interaction with doctors and explanations of their condition, and counselling on medication use. \"So they were actually able to tell us what their experience was and that is important to us,\" he said. Asked about the similarities with the planned health sector exit forms, mentioned recently by Health Minister Dr Fuad Khan, Beharry said the Minister appeared to be on the same \"trend of thought that we have been on\". Harricharan said they had a robust client feedback system, which included the discharge surveys and suggestion boxes at all ERHA facilities, and \"the eastern region can boast a very high resolution rate.\" \"If for example a patient has a complaint...what we do is very actively endeavour to try to resolve same,\" she said On the general feedback from patients, Harricharan noted that she is often complimented about the type of service a patient received from a particular doctor. She praised the staff at the hospital including their \"world-class\" team of consultants. Beharry described the consultants as very committed. \"We don't have stories of our consultants not being on the job,\" he added. Harricharan said they had a lot of doctors and nurses that were very good to patients \"because you go into the hospital and it is something that strikes you. \"Everybody is committed, everybody is diligent, everybody does the best with the resources that we have, I think that generally is the feedback that the general public has of the hospital, and we try very hard to maintain that here,\" she added. Harricharan also noted that they had a committed management team, a lot of them were new as she had to fill a lot of vacancies when she took up the post. She recalled when she became CEO she found a \"very strong and robust hospital system\". \"We are all working very hard to just ensure that what we found when we came here is improved upon,\" she said, She added: \"The (positive) branding of the Sangre Grande Hospital is a result of the good work of the doctors, the nurses, board and management team.\" Speaking on the management style she commented: \"We understand in the Eastern region that health care is not about buildings, we recognise that it has 110 per cent to do with our human resources and so the management style is very collaborative, the managers and the doctors work together hand in hand, there is very open communication between us and them, (similarly with nursing staff), we can monitor what needs there are and our job is to meet their resource needs.\" Harricharan said the hospital is not perfect and has constraints like every hospital including space, but they work in tandem with the Health Ministry. \"We just try hard to really reach the performance targets set by the ministry, and we use the milestones to govern our behaviour and manage staff,\" she said. Beharry noted the hospital had won a lot of quality awards from the Health Ministry. Most recently its male and female medical awards won National Health Sector Quality Awards from the Health Ministry \"for hospitality, personalised and respectful care\". He said that during the assessment the delivery on the ward was \"beyond the call\" of duty including ensuring patients are comfortable and happy. He also pointed out that Sangre Grande has won best secondary care facility for 2008 and 2009, not applying in 2010 due to heavy construction, and the ERHA has won best performing RHA four years in a row due to \"staff working hard to performance measurement targets\". He said the paediatric ward has been changed from clinical in nature to more inviting to the children, including murals, dishes with characters and colourful uniforms for the nurses. They also set up a private room for breast feeding mothers and a play area for the children. At the paediatric ward a letter from a patient was posted on the door thanking the staff for their \"kind\" and \"helpful\" service. There was also a section for the Health Ministry Quality Awards that the ward had won. Beharry said that their kitchen area has been improved with specific patient diets being prepared at the main kitchen for individualised care. During the tour of the hospital the Sunday Express was shown their archiving system, implemented September 2011, which is completely wireless and interlinked with other ERHA facilities. Health officials explained that documents like x-rays can be done in Rio Claro and sent to Sangre Grande Hospital via the system without the need for a physical transfer. Dr Nalini Kokaram-Maharaj at the radiology department said their case load per day was equivalent to Mt Hope or San Fernando General Hospital with less than a third of the staff but while these institutions may have workload dating back a couple years theirs date back a couple of weeks. \"(We are) one of the most if not the most productive of the regions,\" she said. She added that they needed larger facilities and are hoping for funding for an MRI machine in order to be more self-sufficient. They currently have to send patients to Mt Hope and San Fernando General Hospital. Beharry noted they are working on a proposal to take to the Health Ministry to rename Sangre Grande County/District Hospital because it has reached the point where it is a general hospital. Harricharan noted for this fiscal year they are looking to expand their cardiology unit, establish an endoscopy unit and they are \"trying hard\" to open a fourth operating theatre. The second phase of work on their extended care unit should finish in September this year. Other changes include a new pharmacy building, storage area and medical records area, extension of the radiology building and a waiting room for the Intensive Care Unit. \"We try to prioritise with the budget we get every year,\" she added. Beharry noted Sangre Grande Hospital has been one of the fastest growing hospitals in this country and since 2007 they have introduced a lot of new services as they had listened to calls from the catchment population for more services closer to their area. Harricharan noted that patient numbers have increased greatly since the new services were introduced including the ophthalmology clinic (239 per cent), oncology clinic had (150 per cent) and orthopaedics (223 per cent), which \"drives\" them to provide services. She said the number of visits for fiscal 2009-10 has been 75,000 across disciplines. \"In spite of the fact that we don't serve as many patients as some of the other RHAs, what we strive to do here is ensure that the quality of service that we deliver is optimal,\" she said.
